summary: acute lung injury and acute respiratory distress syndrome are serious clinical disorders of the lung. mortality rates resulting from ALI/ARDS in intensive care units remain high at 30% to 40%. many animal models of sepsis have been developed to study ALI. mice lacking caspase-1 are resistant to LPS-induced endotoxic shock. treatment with a specific caspase-1 inhibitor has been shown to reduce LPS-induced lung injury in mice (8). rabbit polyclonal caspase-1 P10 (M-20) antibody was sourced from Santa Cruz, CA. Rabbit polyclonal TLR4, IRF-1, IL-1, and glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) antibody was all from Cell Signaling Technology. the left lung was removed and fixed in 4% paraformaldehyde for 24 h. a total of 10 mL bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) was withdrawn from each mouse. another 2 mL BALF was harvested immediately following sacrifice from other mice to detect the total protein level and cytokine level in the BALF. immunohistochemistry analyses were carried out to determine the expression of cleaved caspase-1 in the lung tissue of mice. sections were routinely stained with antimouse caspase-1 P10 (M-20) at 1:50 (Santa Cruz, CA) reaction products were visualized by treating the slide with 3,3′-diaminobenzidine and counterstaining with hematoxylin. mouse IRF-1mRNA were manufactured by Hanyin (Shanghai, China) the shRNA sequences were as follows: IRF-1 shRNA: 5’- GCACTAAATGAGTCCTATTCC-3’, and nonspecific shRNA: 5′- TTCTCCGAACGTGTCACGT-3′. the lentivirial constructs expressing mouse IRF-1 infused with puromycin resistance genes were manufactured by the same vendor (Hanyin) a total volume of 10 uL was programmed as follows: 95°C for 10 min, 40 cycles at 95°C for 10 s, 60°C for 20 s, and 72°C for 15 s. the sequence of primers used for quantitative PCR was as follows: TLR4 forward: 5′-TTGATACGTTTCCTTATAAG-3′. membranes were incubated overnight at 4°C with primary antibodies against caspase-1 P10 (1:1,000), GAPDH (1:2,000), histone H3 (1:500), IRF-1 (1:1,000), and IL-1 (1:500) after three washes, membranes were incubated with the secondary antibody conjugated with horseradish peroxidase at room temperature for 1 h. J744.A1 cells were transfected with IRF-1 shRNA, control lentivirus vector (NC shRNA), IRF-1 lentivirus (IRF-1 LV) and control lentivirus vector (NC LV) then J744.A1 cells were stimulated with or without LPS (500 ng/mL) for 5 h and ATP (5 mM) was added during the last hour of culture. nuclear and cytoplasmic protein in J744.A1 cells was confirmed by western blotting. transduction of J744.A1 cells with IRF-1 lentivirus vector resulted in significant caspase-1 activation (Fig. 7B, P 0.05; Fig. 6D, P 0.05) compared with the negative control in both LPS/ATP-treated and untreated groups. two milliliters of the supernatants were harvested and tested for levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines. overexpression of IRF-1 in J744.A1 cells boosted expression of IL-18 (A), IL-1 (C) and HMGB1 (E) in the supernatants. we have investigated the role of IRF-1 in mediating AM pyroptosis. we found that tissue-derived alveolar macrophages exhibit less pyroptosis than their WT counterparts. overexpression of IRF-1 in J744.A1 cells alone is a sufficient stimulation to induce pyroptosis. caspase-1-mediated tissue damage is thought to require the pro-inflammatory caspase-1 substrates IL-1 and IL-18. the existence of another caspase-1-dependent mediator of endotoxemia, HMGB1, has been described. this suggests that IRF-1 could play a key role in pyroptosis-associated cytokines. LPS-induced pyroptosis in AMs is a process that is dependent on TLR4-mediated upregulation of IRF-1. our study provides a novel therapeutic approach to management of ALI/ARDS.
